label: Letter from John Ashe to Benjamin Lincoln
description: Letter from John Ashe to Benjamin Lincoln regarding the impending invasion of troops from the other side of the Savannah river and an insistence that there needed to be a strong opposition to meet them in Augusta. Ashe also states that he has enclosed a letter from General Williamson.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from John Ashe to Benjamin Lincoln regarding the impending invasion of troops from the other side of the Savannah river and an insistence that there needed to be a strong opposition to meet them in Augusta. Ashe also states that he has enclosed a letter from General Williamson.

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: For more information contact The Charleston Museum, 360 Meeting Street, Charleston, SC 29403.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 ppi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival Masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[John Ashe to Benjamin Lincoln
February 10, 1779
[RvW Box 1 Folder 25; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Sir,				Steele Creek February 10th, 1779
Agreeable to your orders I proceeded next morning to
General Williamson's Quarters, from the intelligence
I Receivd [sic] there and elswhere [sic], [and] from several of the maneu-
-vres of the Enemy that evening I had the strongest reason
to think they intended to march down on the other side
of the River to cross over and engage the Brigade under
General Bryan, before they made a Junction with
those above, which oblidg'd me to Ride all night [and]
part of yesterday morning to meet them, and
found them thirty miles back of the place I expected.
I am well inform'd from a number of the In-
-habitants on this side the River who converse with
their acquaintance on the opposite side that there
has been for this day or two part a number of
Troops both Hessians [and] others that have march'd
from below to Augusta, where they are already
stronger than I suppos'd them, the back Country
from all accounts will flock to them If they find
they have a superior force to us at Augusta, and
would have done it before this had it not been
reported amongst them, that I was on my march
with thrice the number of Troops that I really
have, which the Enemy now have from their Emissa
‘rys on this side the River an exact account of
It's my opinion Sir, the Preservation of this
State depends upon a Vigourous [sic] opposition
[End Page 1]
against the Troops at Augusta,
I inclose a Letter I
this moment Receivd [sic] from General Williamson.
I am
Sir
With Respect and Esteem
Your most Obedt. Humbl. Servt. [Obedient Humble Servant]
Jno. [John] Ashe
General Lincoln
[Endorsed upside down:] Genl [General] Ashe
[End Page 2]
